text: I'm John Harwood with the New York Times
in CNBC after a six-week loll Democratic
presidential candidates returned to the
debate stage on Wednesday and that means
the trailing candidate Hillary Clinton
has a decision to make whether to be
aggressive or more subdued in her
approach to frontrunner Barack Obama
she's taken both approaches in past
debates and could justify either one
this time since Clinton and Obama last
debated in cleveland on February 26
she's made little progress toward her
goal of a come-from-behind victory she's
further behind in the delegate race and
has failed to overtake Obama in most
national polls despite a brief national
firestorm over incendiary remarks by his
former pastor Jeremiah Wright that
leaves some Democrats predicting she'll
begin steering toward a soft landing for
her campaign which would earn goodwill
within the party and might even end with
her taking the second spot on Barack
Obama's ticket but the new controversy
over Obama's statement about bitterness
of some swing voters and how that
influences their attitudes on religion
and gun rights has given Clinton new
hope if she can hit Obama effectively on
that issue on Wednesday Clinton could
reach every group she's now targeting
voters in Pennsylvania Indiana and other
remaining primary states uncommitted
super-delegates with doubts about
Obama's electability and the media there
are risks if Clinton appears to go too
far in presenting herself as the
champion of gun owners and churchgoers
and it's not yet clear ordinary voters
care about Obama's remarks as much as
the news media even or aids aren't sure
which approach she will take is one
strategist told me in this unpredictable
campaign the debate is still a lifetime
away and any predictions almost
certainly will be wrong
